3.3 Possible origins of the ‘subordinating accent’       As we have seen, stress shift plays an important role in subordination in Karajá. Thisdevice—which we may call ‘subordinating accent’—is reminiscent of the ‘definite accent’ inTonga, described by Anderson (1992: 212) as an example of non-affixal clitic. In thislanguage, according to Anderson, “the normal location of stress is on (the syllablecontaining) the penultimate mora.
